docs.lead_paragraph: In the Hasidic community of Williamsburg, Brooklyn, many people just call it ''moisture cure.'' Its full name is moisture cured urethane, a wood floor resurfacing product with a finish so hard, it's used on basketball courts and bowling alleys, and a vapor so intense that many New York City apartment building managers banned it years ago. But in Jewish Williamsburg, its use has become part of the culture -- a pattern constantly reinforced by word of mouth, residents say, in a corner of New York where the health warnings of the information age mostly do not reach. Televisions, radios and English-language newspapers among the Hasidim are rare.

headline.main: Part Environmentalist, All Rabbi; Fighting to Educate Jewish Williamsburg About a Health Risk

docs.abstract: Rabbi Liba Sofer is trying to educate Hasidic community of Williamsburg, Brooklyn, about hazards of moisture cured urethane on wood floors, which he blames for high incidence of childhood asthma in community and, more controversially, for cancers and miscarriages; has become determined 'noodge' in community and has succeeded in getting bill introduced to City Council that would ban moisture cured urethane in multi-unit apartment buildings throughout city; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Women whose second child had a father different from the first child's were at higher risk for birth complications, a new study has found. Researchers in Norway based the conclusion on a study of births by almost 500,000 women over a 20-year period. Their report appears in BMJ, a British medical journal.
docs.abstract: Dr Lars J Vatten, Norwegian University of Science and Technology researcher, leads study published in BMJ, British medical journal, that finds increased risk of birth complications for mothers whose second child is from different father than first child; studied 500,000 women over 20-year period; suggests doctors and midwives should be aware of increased risk; drawing (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Sex education was an awkward business once. In my school they called the subject ''Health.'' The teacher diagrammed the reproductive organs on a blackboard that still showed the ghosts of algebra problems, then cleared his throat and asked for ''any questions.'' We had plenty, but none we wished to ask him. Too shy. Too polite. And too fearful that our teacher, who we found it hard to believe had had sex recently (we didn't want to picture it if he had), would suffer some sort of fundamental breakdown if our inquiries grew too vivid. Instead, we silently studied our illustrated textbooks while our teacher huddled behind his desk nervously sorting and sharpening colored pencils. While I was reading, I thought I heard one snap. Youngsters today may have it easier, though, thanks to the thus far unacknowledged efforts of anonymous Hollywood sitcom writers. According to a new study, watching TV is a highly effective means of teaching teenagers about sensitive sexual issues like, just to name one, condom leakage. Researchers at the RAND Corporation have found that a single episode of ''Friends'' centering on Rachel's unplanned pregnancy due to the untimely failure of Ross's condom stuck in the heads of most teenagers who viewed it, and especially those who viewed it with an adult and discussed it together afterward. Six months later, RAND found, the teenagers still recalled its gist: life is imperfect and sometimes rubbers rupture.
docs.abstract: Walter Kirn article compares sex education he got in high school 'Health' class with what teenagers today are picking up from television sitcoms; photo (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Zoraida Rodriguez has vivid memories of her childhood. But in the poverty of the Lower East Side, they were far from days of innocence. She recalls sniffing cocaine for the first time when she was 11. She remembers skin-popping -- injecting heroin into her upper arm. Drug rehabilitation for addiction soon followed. And all before she turned 16.

headline.main: The Neediest Cases; A Mother Battles to Break a Vicious Cycle of Addiction

docs.abstract: UJA-Federation of New York helps mother on Lower East Side who is trying to kick her addiction to drugs; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: CONSIDER the title: ''Entertaining Mr. Sloane.'' Sloane is a 17-year-old hustler -- boyish and fair, but manipulative and trashy. One doesn't call him Mister.
docs.abstract: Alvin Klein reviews Fleetwood Stage production of Joe Orton play Entertaining Mr Sloane, directed by Paul Carlin; Billy Lush, Ruth Moore and Lewis Arit star; photo (M)
